SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.abmash.api
Class HtmlQuery

java.lang.Object
  com.abmash.api.HtmlQuery

public class HtmlQuery
extends java.lang.Object

Find elements by specifying query conditions for the current active web page, used by calling Browser.query().

Examples:

  • browser.query().has("result").findFirst(); searches for elements containing the attribute or inner text result
  • browser.query().isTitle().findFirst(); searches for title elements, i.e. <h1>, <h2>, ... <h6> and any element with a bigger font-size than the default on the current page
  • browser.query().root(myHtmlElement).isClickable().findFirst(); searches for all clickable elements like links and buttons which are child elements of myHtmlElement
  • browser.query().below(myHtmlElement).isImage().has("description").findFirst(); searches for all image elements with are below myHtmlElement and have an attribute or inner text description

Description:

Create a new query instance by calling browser.query(). Conditions can be chained one after another. To get the matching HtmlElements or HtmlElement, call find() or findFirst().

Author:
Alper Ortac

Constructor Detail

HtmlQuery

public HtmlQuery(Browser browser)
Creates a new query instance for finding HtmlElements on the current page.

Parameters:
browser - the browser instance to use for finding elements
Method Detail

childOf

public HtmlQuery childOf(HtmlElements rootElements)
Defines root elements from which to search on.

Each element will be searched separately. Only descendants will be searched whereas ancestors will be ignored.

Parameters:
rootElements - the root elements
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

childOf

public HtmlQuery childOf(HtmlElement rootElement)
Defines a root element from which to search on.

Only descendants will be searched whereas ancestors will be ignored.

Parameters:
rootElements - the root elements
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

not

public HtmlQuery not(HtmlQuery notQuery)
Defines a "NOT" subquery. The position of the subquery in the condition chain does not matter and is ignored.

Note that the find() method of the subquery it automatically called. If only one (or another amount) of the result elements shall be returned, use limit(1).

Parameters:
notQuery - the HtmlQuery to be combined as NOT condition
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
limit(Integer)

or

public HtmlQuery or(HtmlQuery orQuery)
Defines an "OR" subquery. The position of the subquery in the condition chain does not matter and is ignored.

Note that the find() method of the subquery it automatically called. If only one (or another amount) of the result elements shall be returned, use limit(1).

Parameters:
orQuery - the HtmlQuery to be combined as OR condition
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
limit(Integer)

has

public HtmlQuery has(java.lang.String query)
Finds elements which contain the specified text or having an attribute value containing the query.

Exact matches have more weight than partial matches. In most cases the query is case-sensitive.

Examples:

  • browser.query().has("Name").findFirst() finds the first element which contains the text Name
  • browser.query().isInList().has("April").find() finds all elements in a list which contain the text April

Parameters:
query - text or attribute value to search for, case-sensitive
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

tag

public HtmlQuery tag(java.lang.String name)
Finds elements by their tag name.

Examples:

  • browser.query().tag("a").findFirst() finds the first link element on the current page
  • browser.query().has("Today").tag("p").find() finds all paragraph elements which contain the text Today

Parameters:
elementType -
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

isText

public HtmlQuery isText()
Finds text elements, which is the most general search criteria. It prefers text passages, paragraphs, blocks, list items or table cells, but returns any element if there are no other matches.

isText() should usually be used in combination with has(String).

Examples:

  • browser.query().isText().has("Hello").find() finds all elements containing the text Hello

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

isTitle

public HtmlQuery isTitle()
Finds title elements, which are all elements with headline tags(<h1>, <h2>, ..., <h6>) and elements with a bigger font size than the default one.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isTitle().find() finds all title elements
  • browser.query().isTitle().isClickable().find() finds all clickable title elements
  • browser.query().isTitle().isClickable().has("Article").find() finds all clickable title elements containing the text Article

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

isClickable

public HtmlQuery isClickable()
Finds clickable elements like links and buttons.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isClickable().find() finds all clickable elements like links or buttons, see also Browser.click(String)
  • HtmlElements clickablesInTable = browser.query().isClickable().isInTable().find() finds all clickable elements in table cells
  • ArrayList<String> urls = clickablesInTable.getUrls() extracts all URLs from the clickable items, see also HtmlElement#getUrl(String) and HtmlElements.getUrls().

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.click(String)

isTypable

public HtmlQuery isTypable()
Finds typable elements like input fields, text areas or rich-text-editors like tinyMCE, which can be used to enter text.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isTypable().find() finds all typable elements which can be used to enter text, see also Browser.type(String, String)
  • HtmlElement input = browser.query().isTypable().has("address").findFirst() finds text input labeled address
  • input.type("Miller Street 123").submit() enters the text Miller Street 123 in the text field and submits the form, see also HtmlElement.type(String), HtmlElement.submit() is optional.

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.type(String, String)

isChoosable

public HtmlQuery isChoosable()
Finds selectable elements, which are usually drop-down boxes or input boxes with multiple selectable items.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isChoosable().find() finds all choosable elements, see also Browser.choose(String, String)
  • HtmlElement language = browser.query().isChoosable().has("Language").findFirst() finds choosable labeled Language
  • language.select("English").submit() selects the language item labeled English and submit the form, see also HtmlElement.choose(String), HtmlElement.submit() is optional.

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

isImage

public HtmlQuery isImage()
Finds image elements. Images defined as background image can not be found properly at the moment.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isImage().find() finds all image elements on the current page

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

isList

public HtmlQuery isList()
Finds list elements, which are the root elements of lists, usually <ul>, <ol> or <dl> elements.

Examples:

  • HtmlElement list = browser.query().isList().has("Country").findFirst() finds first list element labeled or containing the text Country, see also Browser.getList(String)
  • List countryList = browser.getList(list) returns the list representation of that element, see also Browser.getList(HtmlElement)
  • list.get(0) gets the first item of that list, see also List.get(int)

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.getList(HtmlElement), Browser.getList(String), List

isInList

public HtmlQuery isInList()
Finds elements in lists, which are usually <li> or <dt> elements.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isInList().has("Name").find() finds all elements in a list, which are labeled Name

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.getList(HtmlElement), Browser.getList(String), List

isTable

public HtmlQuery isTable()
Finds table elements, which are the root elements of tables, usually <table> elements.

Examples:

  • HtmlElement table = browser.query().isTable().has("Version").findFirst() finds first table element labeled or containing the text Version, see also Browser.getTable(String)
  • Table countryTable = browser.getTable(table) returns the table representation of that element, see also Browser.getTable(HtmlElement)
  • table.getCell(0,0) gets the cell in the upper left corner of that table, see also Table.getCell(int, int)
  • see Table for more examples how to handle Table representations

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.getTable(HtmlElement), Browser.getTable(String), Table

isInTable

public HtmlQuery isInTable()
Finds elements in tables, which are usually <td> or <th> elements.

Examples:

  • browser.query().isInTable().has("$").find() finds all elements in a table, which contain the character $

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.getTable(HtmlElement), Browser.getTable(String), Table

isFrame

public HtmlQuery isFrame()
Finds frame elements, which are parts of the page with separated content, usually <frame> and <iframe> elements.

Examples:

  • HtmlElement frame = browser.query().isFrame().findFirst() finds the first frame on the page, see also Browser.frame() for switching directly (set focus) to a frame
  • browser.frame().switchTo(frame) sets focus on the selected frame. all browser interactions will take place in this frame from now on

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
Browser.frame()

closestTo

public HtmlQuery closestTo(HtmlElements referenceElements,
                           com.abmash.core.browser.htmlquery.condition.ClosenessCondition.Direction direction)
Finds elements visually close to the given reference elements.

The Direction determines if found elements will be filtered out in case they are visually at another location. The found elements will be automatically ordered by closeness to the referenceElements. The distance is calculated by the euclidean measure.

Parameters:
referenceElements -
direction - see ClosenessCondition.Direction for a description of all possible values
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

closestTo

public HtmlQuery closestTo(java.lang.String query)
Finds elements visually close to the given reference element with the specified label.

The found elements will be automatically ordered by closeness to the referenceElements. The distance is calculated by the euclidean measure.

Parameters:
query - the visible label or hidden attribute of the element
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

closestTo

public HtmlQuery closestTo(HtmlElement referenceElement)
Finds elements visually close to the given reference element.

The found elements will be automatically ordered by closeness to the referenceElements. The distance is calculated by the euclidean measure.

Parameters:
referenceElement - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

closestToAny

public HtmlQuery closestToAny(HtmlElements referenceElements)
Finds elements visually close to the given reference elements.

The found elements will be automatically ordered by closeness to the referenceElements. The distance is calculated by the euclidean measure.

Parameters:
referenceElements - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

above

public HtmlQuery above(java.lang.String query)
Finds elements above the element with the specified label.

Elements are above if their bottom y coordinate is lower than the top y coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in horizontal bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
              ----------
              - <span> -
              ----------
        ---------
        - <div> -
        ---------
   --------
   - <ul> -
   --------
In this example, the <div> is above the <ul>, but the <span> is not because its left border is not in horizontal bounds of <ul>. Then again, the <span> is above the <div>.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Parameters:
query - the visible label or hidden attribute of the element
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

above

public HtmlQuery above(HtmlElement referenceElement)
Finds elements above the reference element.

Elements are above if their bottom y coordinate is lower than the top y coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in horizontal bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
              ----------
              - <span> -
              ----------
        ---------
        - <div> -
        ---------
   --------
   - <ul> -
   --------
In this example, the <div> is above the <ul>, but the <span> is not because its left border is not in horizontal bounds of <ul>. Then again, the <span> is above the <div>.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Parameters:
referenceElement - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

aboveAny

public HtmlQuery aboveAny(HtmlElements referenceElements)
Finds elements visually above any of the given reference elements.

Elements are above if their bottom y coordinate is lower than the top y coordinate of any reference element. In addition, the element has to be in horizontal bounds of any reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
             ----------
             - <span> -
             ----------
        ---------   ---------
        - <div> -   - <div> -
        ---------   ---------
   --------            --------
   - <ul> -            - <ul> -
   --------            --------
If the <ul>s are the reference elements in this example, the <div>s are above the <ul>s, but the <span> is not because its left and right border is not in horizontal bounds of any of the <ul>s. Then again, the <span> is above from both of the <div>s, if they are the reference elements.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to any of the reference elements.

Parameters:
referenceElements - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
above(HtmlElement)

aboveAll

public HtmlQuery aboveAll(HtmlElements referenceElements)
Finds elements visually above all of the given reference elements.

Elements are above if their bottom y coordinate is lower than the top y coordinate of any reference element. In addition, the element has to be in horizontal bounds of any reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
             ----------
             - <span> -
             ----------
        ---------   ---------
        - <div> -   - <div> -
        ---------   ---------
   --------            --------
   - <ul> -            - <ul> -
   --------            --------
If the <ul>s are the reference elements in this example, the <div>s and also the <span> are not above them, because they are not above from at least one of the <ul>s. But if the <div>s are the reference elements, the <span> is above both of them.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to any of the reference elements.

Parameters:
referenceElements - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
above(HtmlElement)

below

public HtmlQuery below(java.lang.String query)
Finds elements below the element with the specified label.

Elements are below if their top y coordinate is higher than the bottom y coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in horizontal bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
   --------
   - <ul> -
   --------
        ---------
        - <div> -
        ---------
              ----------
              - <span> -
              ----------
In this example, the <div> is below the <ul>, but the <span> is not because its left border is not in horizontal bounds of <ul>. Then again, the <span> is below the <div>.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Parameters:
query - the visible label or hidden attribute of the element
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

leftTo

public HtmlQuery leftTo(java.lang.String query)
Finds elements left to the element with the specified label.

Elements are left if their right x coordinate is lower than the left x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
                    ----------
   --------         - <span> -
   - <ul> -         ----------
   --------   ---------
              - <div> -
              ---------
In this example, the <ul> is left to the <span> and to the <div>, but the <div> is not left to the <span>, because its top border is not in vertical bounds of <span>.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Parameters:
query - the visible label or hidden attribute of the element
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

leftTo

public HtmlQuery leftTo(HtmlElement referenceElement)
Finds elements left to the reference element.

Elements are left if their right x coordinate is lower than the left x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
                    ----------
   --------         - <span> -
   - <ul> -         ----------
   --------   ---------
              - <div> -
              ---------
In this example, the <ul> is left to the <span> and to the <div>, but the <div> is not left to the <span>, because its top border is not in vertical bounds of <span>.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

leftToAny

public HtmlQuery leftToAny(HtmlElements referenceElements)
Finds elements visually left to any of the given reference elements.

Elements are left if their right x coordinate is lower than the left x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.                          
                            --------
                            - <ul> -
                ---------   --------
                - <div> -
    ----------  ---------
    - <span> -
    ---------- ----------
                - <div> -
                ---------   --------
                            - <ul> -
                            --------
If the <ul>s are the reference elements in this example, the <div>s are left to the <ul>s, but the <span> is not because its top and bottom border is not in vertical bounds of any of the <ul>s. Then again, the <span> is left to both of the <div>s, if they are the reference elements.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to any of the reference elements.

Parameters:
referenceElements - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
leftTo(HtmlElement)

leftToAll

public HtmlQuery leftToAll(HtmlElements referenceElements)
Finds elements visually left to all of the given reference elements.

Elements are left if their right x coordinate is lower than the left x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
                            --------
                            - <ul> -
                ---------   --------
                - <div> -
    ----------  ---------
    - <span> -
    ---------- ----------
                - <div> -
                ---------   --------
                            - <ul> -
                            --------
If the <ul>s are the reference elements in this example, the <div>s and also the <span> are not left to them, because they are not left to at least one of the <ul>s. But if the <div>s are the reference elements, the <span> is left to both of them.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to any of the reference elements.

Parameters:
referenceElements - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
leftTo(HtmlElement)

rightTo

public HtmlQuery rightTo(java.lang.String query)
Finds elements right to the element with the specified label.

Elements are right if their left x coordinate is higher than the right x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
                       ----------
   --------            - <span> -
   - <ul> -            ----------
   --------  ---------
             - <div> -
             ---------
In this example, the <span> and the <div> are right to the <ul>, but the <span> is not right to the <div> because its bottom border is not in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Parameters:
query - the visible label or hidden attribute of the element
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

rightTo

public HtmlQuery rightTo(HtmlElement referenceElement)
Finds elements right to the reference element.

Elements are right if their left x coordinate is higher than the right x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
                       ----------
   --------            - <span> -
   - <ul> -            ----------
   --------  ---------
             - <div> -
             ---------
In this example, the <span> and the <div> are right to the <ul>, but the <span> is not right to the <div> because its bottom border is not in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to the reference element.

Parameters:
referenceElement - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

rightToAny

public HtmlQuery rightToAny(HtmlElements referenceElements)
Finds elements visually right to any of the given reference elements.

Elements are right if their left x coordinate is higher than the right x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
   --------
   - <ul> -
   --------   ---------
              - <div> -
              ---------  ----------
                         - <span> -
              ---------  ----------
              - <div> -
   --------   ---------
   - <ul> -
   --------
If the <ul>s are the reference elements in this example, the <div>s are right to the <ul>s, but the <span> is not because its top and bottom borders are not in vertical bounds of any of the <ul>s. Then again, the <span> is right to both of the <div>s, if they are the reference elements.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to any of the reference elements.

Parameters:
referenceElements - elements which are taken as reference for measuring the distance
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()
See Also:
rightTo(HtmlElement)

public HtmlQuery rightToAll(HtmlElements referenceElements)

Elements are right if their left x coordinate is higher than the right x coordinate of the reference element. In addition, the element has to be in vertical bounds of the reference element.

Example: (visual representation of the web page) 

.
   --------
   - <ul> -
   --------   ---------
              - <div> -
              ---------  ----------
                         - <span> -
              ---------  ----------
              - <div> -
   --------   ---------
   - <ul> -
   --------
If the <ul>s are the reference elements in this example, the <div>s and also the <span> are not right to them, because they are not right to at least one of the <ul>s. But if the <div>s are the reference elements, the <span> is right to both of them.

Calling find() will order the result by closeness, so that the first result is the closest element to any of the reference elements.

limit

public HtmlQuery limit(java.lang.Integer count)
Limits the result set to the specified amount.

Parameters:
count - maximum number of results, no limit if null
Returns:
this HtmlQuery instance, which can be used to add more search criteria like this or to finally execute the query with find() or findFirst()

find

public HtmlElements find()
Finds all elements which match the given search conditions.

Returns null if no element was found.

Returns:
the HtmlElements result set

findFirst

public HtmlElement findFirst()
Finds best matching element which match the given search conditions.

Returns null if no element was found.

Returns:
the HtmlElement result
